title: Possibility to freeze/crash the host system of all Slack Desktop users easily

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
Hello,

I report here what I suspect to be a critical issue for all your users using the Slack Desktop app.
Please find below my research way and the corresponding POC result:

First, I started by exploring the content of the file **app.asar** of the Slack Dresktop application.
I was firstly attrackted by the file **parse-protocol-url.js** and more particularly on the following lines:

```javascript
const expressionsToMatch = [{
  regex: /devEnv=(dev\d*|staging|qa\d*)/,
  onMatch: (match) => ({ devMode: true, devEnv: match[1] })
}
```
I immediately tried the URL `slack://open?devEnv=staging` in my browser and it was working as expected:

{F330966}

The issue started whan I noted the fact that if I reload my browser, I will have a second Slack Desktop process with a second interface. This is not the case when I use the url `slack://open` openning the normal prod interface. So, even if I can imagine this behavior as practical for your developers (having two Slack Desktop applications at the same time, one one the production environment and one on the staging/dev/qa environment), the fact to be able to launch infinite Slack Desktop application should be forbidden.

I click 9 times on **F5** in my browser and below was the result:

{F330971}
{F330972}

You can test this fact on your side with the simple POC page in attachment : {F330973}

On my side, with 32Go of RAM and a i7-6820HQ CPU 2.70, I freezed my PC easily with the test **100 Slack Apps - Not Funny!**

You will not have this issue if you use the url `slack://open` where only the CPU can be used at 100% depending of how many requests you launch:

{F330972}

With the url  `slack://open?devEnv=staging` you will have quickly % of CPU usage and a memory usage increasing quickly.

The security aspect here is on the availability of the application.

## Impact

An attacker can use this lack of control in order and through a simple link ( or a batch file for windows or a script for linux, etc ... ) can crash and/or freeze all customers using your Slack Desktop application. I did not test on Linux or Mac but I suspect that the effects are the same.

I recommand you to put in place the same control that the one on production environment: if one slack desktop application is already launched on the staging/dev[xxx]/qa[xxx] platform, do not launch a second one but just give the focus on the existing one.

What do you think?
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello,

I report here what I suspect to be a critical issue for all your users using the Slack Desktop app.
Please find below my research way and the corresponding POC result:

First, I started by exploring the content of the file app.asar of the Slack Dresktop application.
I was firstly attrackted by the file parse-protocol-url.js and more particularly on the following lines:

const expressionsToMatch = [{
  regex: /devEnv=(dev\d*|staging|qa\d*)/,
  onMatch: (match) => ({ devMode: true, devEnv: match[1] })
}

I immediately tried the URL slack://open?devEnv=staging in my browser and it was working as expected:

The issue started whan I noted the fact that if I reload my browser, I will have a second Slack Desktop process with a second interface. This is not the case when I use the url slack://open openning the normal prod interface. So, even if I can imagine this behavior as practical for your developers (having two Slack Desktop applications at the same time, one one the production environment and one on the staging/dev/qa environment), the fact to be able to launch infinite Slack Desktop application should be forbidden.

I click 9 times on F5 in my browser and below was the result:


You can test this fact on your side with the simple POC page in attachment : MultiSlackApps.html (F330973)

On my side, with 32Go of RAM and a i7-6820HQ CPU 2.70, I freezed my PC easily with the test 100 Slack Apps - Not Funny!

You will not have this issue if you use the url slack://open where only the CPU can be used at 100% depending of how many requests you launch:

With the url slack://open?devEnv=staging you will have quickly % of CPU usage and a memory usage increasing quickly.

The security aspect here is on the availability of the application.

Impact

An attacker can use this lack of control in order and through a simple link ( or a batch file for windows or a script for linux, etc ... ) can crash and/or freeze all customers using your Slack Desktop application. I did not test on Linux or Mac but I suspect that the effects are the same.

I recommand you to put in place the same control that the one on production environment: if one slack desktop application is already launched on the staging/dev[xxx]/qa[xxx] platform, do not launch a second one but just give the focus on the existing one.

What do you think?

activities.message:
Hi,

Reproducible: My report contains clear, concise steps to reproduce the vulnerability. I provided POC, code, and results.
Impact: My report describes exactly what outcome an attacker would reasonably achieve. In this case, a freeze of the host system of all the slack desktop users.
In Scope: I have carefully reviewed the Slack security page, twice.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

Reproducible: My report contains clear, concise steps to reproduce the vulnerability. I provided POC, code, and results.
Impact: My report describes exactly what outcome an attacker would reasonably achieve. In this case, a freeze of the host system of all the slack desktop users.
In Scope: I have carefully reviewed the Slack security page, twice.

activities.message:

Is my confirmation included in my previous comment sufficient for you? Is it possible to forward to the program? Thanks for your reply.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi hackerone !

Is my confirmation included in my previous comment sufficient for you? Is it possible to forward to the program? Thanks for your reply.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

Just to be clear I am understanding the attack vector you are reporting, are you saying that in order to attack another user, you would need to get the victim to download and execute a malicious batch file (or other executable) on their local system?  If this is the case, this already grants an enormous amount of power to an attacker.  If we assume that attacker could get a victim to do this, crashing the system would likely be the least of what they could do, and probably wouldn't require the Slack app at all to do it.  If we assume that an attacker can get a victim to download and run a malicious file in this way, there simply nothing Slack can do to prevent harm from befalling the victim, regardless of any changes to the desktop app.

Please let me know if I am missing something here or if there is another way to perform this attack.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

Just to be clear I am understanding the attack vector you are reporting, are you saying that in order to attack another user, you would need to get the victim to download and execute a malicious batch file (or other executable) on their local system? If this is the case, this already grants an enormous amount of power to an attacker. If we assume that attacker could get a victim to do this, crashing the system would likely be the least of what they could do, and probably wouldn't require the Slack app at all to do it. If we assume that an attacker can get a victim to download and run a malicious file in this way, there simply nothing Slack can do to prevent harm from befalling the victim, regardless of any changes to the desktop app.

Please let me know if I am missing something here or if there is another way to perform this attack.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Hello,

Sorry if my report was not clear but I think you did not understoof my english.

Slack has their Windows/Linux/Mac Desktop application in the program scope.
With the scenario descrived here, the victims (Slack users having their Slack Desktop application already installed on their system (and I think they are numerous)) just need to click on the button provided on the POC html page in attachment. It means that the attacker just need to share/send a link , the javascript used into the POC exemple can be executed at the page load. So, victims click on the link and the problem arrives. It took 3 minutes for me in order to crash my PC with 32Go of memory. Other vectors like batch or scripts files were just for alerting on the fact that the way to execute can be varied.

Is my explanation more clear now? I hope so.

Thanks

It took 3 minutes for me in order to crash my PC with 32Go of memory. Other vectors like batch or scripts files were just for alerting on the fact that the way to execute can be varied.

Is my explanation more clear now? I hope so.

Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh Here is a full POC, requiring still less victim's interaction. I reminder the fact that the victims are Slack users having the windows, linux, or mac Slack Desktop application installed ( numerous people I think). It will work for old customers having not uninstalled the Slack Desktop application from their systems. As one of these victims, for the POC, copy/paste the below short code into a file named `POC.html` and open this file from one of your browser. Just load and observe the result. ```javascript BUBBOUNTY - MULTI SLACK APPS

MULTI SLACK APPS ON PAGE LOAD

``` Of course, this is a POC here. In a real scenario, the attacker hosts the page somewhere and spread the link. Cheers, @bubbounty
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh

Here is a full POC, requiring still less victim's interaction.
I reminder the fact that the victims are Slack users having the windows, linux, or mac Slack Desktop application installed ( numerous people I think). It will work for old customers having not uninstalled the Slack Desktop application from their systems.

As one of these victims, for the POC, copy/paste the below short code into a file named POC.html and open this file from one of your browser. Just load and observe the result.

<html>
    <head>
        <title>BUBBOUNTY - MULTI SLACK APPS</title>
        <script>
            function MultiSlackStaging(number) {
                for (var i = 0; i < number; i++) {
                    window.open("slack://open?devEnv=staging","_self");
                }
            }
        </script>
    </head>
    <body onload="MultiSlackStaging(10)">
        <h1>MULTI SLACK APPS ON PAGE LOAD</h1>
    </body>
</html>

Of course, this is a POC here. In a real scenario, the attacker hosts the page somewhere and spread the link.

Cheers,
@bubbounty

activities.message: Hi @bubbounty thanks for your patience! It's long due to the priority of the bug. To provide a bit more clarification about the priority - this is a DOS attack, which is actually out of the scope of our bug bounty program. We appreciate the means of exploitation here and the inconvenience which it can cause, so we are fixing it (and we do appreciate your report!) but we are prioritizing this with issues that go beyond annoyance and cause higher severity exploits. I'll update shortly!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @bubbounty thanks for your patience! It's long due to the priority of the bug. I'll update shortly!

activities.message:
Hey @bubbounty,

We wanted to reach out and let you know that we're going to *temporarily* cancel your disclosure request on this ticket.  HackerOne's automated disclosure process would otherwise go through in a day or two, and we want to make sure we give your report appropriate consideration before it becomes public.  As soon as we complete our review (likely next week), we will contact you about disclosure.

Please let us know if you have any questions, and we apologize for the delay.

Please let us know if you have any questions, and we apologize for the delay.

summaries.content:
Here is one of my first  ( valid ) report as hunter.

I found an easy way, requesting minimal victim interaction execpted the simple fact to click on a link, to crash the victim's host quickly. It was possible throught  a slack URL used for accessing to the Staging environment : `slack://open?devEnv=staging` .  When used, there had no check if a Slack instance was already opened and by hence an infinite number of instances could be started.
The result was a quick CPU and RAM overhelmed finally resulting to a sustem's crash.

I provided a simple POC page showing the issue with different levels ( 10 instances, 20, 50, 1à00, 1000 ).
summaries.content_html:
Here is one of my first ( valid ) report as hunter.

I found an easy way, requesting minimal victim interaction execpted the simple fact to click on a link, to crash the victim's host quickly. It was possible throught a slack URL used for accessing to the Staging environment : slack://open?devEnv=staging . When used, there had no check if a Slack instance was already opened and by hence an infinite number of instances could be started.
The result was a quick CPU and RAM overhelmed finally resulting to a sustem's crash.

I provided a simple POC page showing the issue with different levels ( 10 instances, 20, 50, 1à00, 1000 ).
